data: The text is placed on the floor of the vessel, arranged in a clockwise spiral.
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana

An outstanding collection of archaeological material. The collection ranges from Siracusa and the surrounding territory (Megara Hyblaia, Akrai, Kasmenai etc) to encompass all of eastern Sicily, reaching as far as Gela and Agrigento. The ground floor covers prehistory through to the end of the Classical period. Upstairs includes Hellenistic and Roman Syracuse and a display of material from the catacombs. A gallery displaying material from Hellenistic eastern Sicily is in preparation.

Inscriptions grecques dialectales de Sicile : contribution à l'étude du vocabulaire grec colonial
L. Dubois, Inscriptions Grecques Dialectales de Sicile : Contribution à l’étude Du Vocabulaire Grec Colonial, CEFR 119 (Rome: Ecole française de Rome, 1989)
Un vase parlant de Sélinonte (SEG XXIX,938)

La Sicile et le monde grec archaïque. L'apport de la linguistique
O. Masson, “La Sicile et Le Monde Grec Archaïque. L’apport de La Linguistique,” Kokalos 30–31, no. 1 (1985 1984): 71–77
B. Forssman, “Ἀννεμοτα in Einer Dorischen Gefässinschrift,” Münchener Studien Zur Sprachwissenschaft 34 (1976): 39–46
C. Gallavotti, “Letture Epigrafiche,” Quaderni Urbinati Di Cultura Classica 20 (1975): 165–91
I nomi dei vasi greci nelle iscrizioni dei vasi stessi
M.L. Lazzarini, “I Nomi Dei Vasi Greci Nelle Iscrizioni Dei Vasi Stessi,” Archeologia Classica 25–26 (1974 1973): 341–75
M.T. Lazzarini, “Un’iscrizione Vascolare Arcaica Della Sicilia,” Atti Della Accademia Nazionale Dei Lincei, Classe Di Scienze Morali, Storiche e Filologiche. Rendiconti. 28 (1973): 695–98
Intervento: segnalazioni di epigrafia greca; iscrizioni da Montagna di Marzo
Giacomo Manganaro, “Intervento: segnalazioni di epigrafia greca; iscrizioni da Montagna di Marzo,” Kokalos 14–15 (1965 1964): 195–202

τοῦτον τὸν σϙύφον  ἀποδίδο̄τι ἐς τὸν θίασον το͂ν πν
                    αἰ δὲ φίλε̄  οὐκ ἄλλος κ’ ἄγε̄ 
                    hο δὲ γράπσας τὸν ἀννέμοτα πυγιξεῖ

Porkos returns this skyphos to the thiasos of the drinkers.
                       Since he is in love with Phryna, it is not another who will take her.
                       He has written, the one who reads will practice sodomy.

Porkos restituisce questo skyphos al tiaso dei bevitori.
                       Poiché ama Phryna, non è certo un altro che la prenderà.
                       Lui ha scritto, colui che legge praticherà la sodomia.

Text engraved in a spiral pattern on the floor of a kylix that is, however, identified by the inscription as a skyphos. 
                    Forssman's reading gave a better understanding of the text, which would be a joke engraved on the cup for use in a 
                    symposial context. Manganaro speculated that this was an invitation to κοτταβίζειν. Dubois hypothesised that one could think of an 
                    object used in the symposium and that the inscription refers to a scurrilous game intended for the drinker who emptied the cup in question 
                    and found the inscription. 
                    Unusual is not only the type of text and its layout but also the onomastics. The name Πόρϙος is attested only in this inscription 
                    by epigraphy and in an Alcmanes (Fr. 1.1.19) verse known indirectly by Hesychius (ν 516) Νηρεύς· θαλάσσιος δαίμων. Ἀλκμὰν 
                    καὶ Πόρκον ὀνομάζει. Φρύνᾱ occurs also elsewhere, although rarely (two occurrences in total, at Thebes and Thespiai). 
                    Given the interplay of the inscription, Dubois assumed that this last name referred to a female courtesan.
                    The gap at l. 1 was reconstructed by Manganaro as π[οτᾶ]ν, an integration we accept. It is also possible to read, with Dubois, φίλη as 
                    an archaic present indicative (the form would be akin, as the scholar notes, to similar ones in Theocritus, cf. ὅρη in Theoc. XXX.22).
                    The word form ἀννέμο<ν>τα has been interpreted by Forssamn and Gallavotti, with whom later editors agree, 
                    as the accusative of the participle of ἀνανέμω (= ἀναγιγνώσκω), with ellipsis of the nasal, on the basis of its use by Epicarmus and Theocritus. 
                    Gallavotti recognises the segment between the beginning of line 2 and γράπσας as a hexameter and the following syllables as an iambic cadence.

Facsimile Images

1ΤΟΥΤΟΝΤΟΝΣϘΥΦΟΝΠΟΡϘΟΣΑΠΟΔΙΔΟ̄ΤΙΕΣΤΟΝΘΙΑΣΟΝΤΟΝΠ[...]Ν
2ΑΙΔΕΦΙΛΕ̄ΦΡΥΝᾹΝΟΥΚΑΛΛΟΣΚΑΓΕ̄
3HΟΔΕΓΡΑΠΣΑΣΤΟΝΑΝΝΕΜΟΤΑΠΥΓΙΞΕΙ

Apparatus criticus

  • Text after Dubois (IGDS 1) ;
  • 1: Manganaro, Arena: π[ᾱο͂]ν
  • 2: Arena: δ’ἐφίλε̄ ... ἆγε

English translation

Porkos returns this skyphos to the thiasos of the drinkers. Since he is in love with Phryna, it is not another who will take her. He has written, the one who reads will practice sodomy.

Italian translation

Porkos restituisce questo skyphos al tiaso dei bevitori. Poiché ama Phryna, non è certo un altro che la prenderà. Lui ha scritto, colui che legge praticherà la sodomia.

commentary

Text engraved in a spiral pattern on the floor of a kylix that is, however, identified by the inscription as a skyphos. Forssman's reading gave a better understanding of the text, which would be a joke engraved on the cup for use in a symposial context. Manganaro speculated that this was an invitation to κοτταβίζειν. Dubois hypothesised that one could think of an object used in the symposium and that the inscription refers to a scurrilous game intended for the drinker who emptied the cup in question and found the inscription. Unusual is not only the type of text and its layout but also the onomastics. The name Πόρϙος is attested only in this inscription by epigraphy and in an Alcmanes (Fr. 1.1.19) verse known indirectly by Hesychius (ν 516) Νηρεύς· θαλάσσιος δαίμων. Ἀλκμὰν καὶ Πόρκον ὀνομάζει. Φρύνᾱ occurs also elsewhere, although rarely (two occurrences in total, at Thebes and Thespiai). Given the interplay of the inscription, Dubois assumed that this last name referred to a female courtesan. The gap at l. 1 was reconstructed by Manganaro as π[οτᾶ]ν, an integration we accept. It is also possible to read, with Dubois, φίλη as an archaic present indicative (the form would be akin, as the scholar notes, to similar ones in Theocritus, cf. ὅρη in Theoc. XXX.22). The word form ἀννέμο<ν>τα has been interpreted by Forssamn and Gallavotti, with whom later editors agree, as the accusative of the participle of ἀνανέμω (= ἀναγιγνώσκω), with ellipsis of the nasal, on the basis of its use by Epicarmus and Theocritus. Gallavotti recognises the segment between the beginning of line 2 and γράπσας as a hexameter and the following syllables as an iambic cadence.

Text engraved in a spiral pattern on the floor of a kylix that is, however, identified by the inscription as a skyphos. Forssman's reading gave a better understanding of the text, which would be a joke engraved on the cup for use in a symposial context. Manganaro speculated that this was an invitation to κοτταβίζειν. Dubois hypothesised that one could think of an object used in the symposium and that the inscription refers to a scurrilous game intended for the drinker who emptied the cup in question and found the inscription. Gallavotti recognises the segment between the beginning of line 2 and γράπσας as a hexameter and the following syllables as an iambic cadence.
